context:
Listener: I think you are an excellent person . Honestly speaking , you are very suitable for this job
Speaker: Thank you very much for your evaluation . I also like this job very much .
Listener: I want to know your earliest available entry time .
Speaker: Oh , let me think ... Maybe two months later .
Listener: It's too late . If you could get the job , could you start a little earlier ?
Speaker: I'm sorry I can't , because I haven't finished my thesis .
Listener: What a pity !
Speaker: When do you usually require the new employee to start ?
Listener: Within two weeks , because the new employees need to receive induction training .
Speaker: I will make an arrangement for it .
Listener: I hope you can come to our company to work .
Speaker: I will give you an exact reply as soon as possible .
question: What might happen after what Speaker just said?
a1: after this, the listener might follow up with the speaker in a week or two to see if they've made a decision yet.
a2: the speaker finishes his thesis as soon as possible and informs the listener that he will join the company next week.

context:
Listener: 911.
Speaker: Help. I need some help!
Listener: Yes sir. Can you tell me what is happening?
Speaker: I'm at the university and a student of mine suddenly fell down, knocked her head on the step, and fainted right at this very moment.
Listener: Yes sir. Can you tell me exactly where you are?
Speaker: On the...on the ...I'm sorry, I'm too nervous right now. We're on the second floor of Cutler Hall, Room 211.
Listener: I understand, sir. May I have your name and the student's name?
Speaker: Her name is...uh...Anita Rivera. And my name's Lawrence Clark. I'm a professor here at the university.
Listener: Okay, who is there with you?
Speaker: Um, Anita and two other students. They're watching her while I call. Do you think we should drive her to the hospital?
Listener: No, an ambulance is already on its way. It should be there very soon.
Speaker: Uh, what should we do while we wait for it to come?
Listener: Just keep her calm and warm.
Speaker: Okay, well do that. Thank you.
question: What might happen after what Speaker just said?
a1: the professor gathers several warm blankets and puts them around anita to keep her warm.
a2: after this, the ambulance arrives and the paramedics take anita to the hospital for further treatment.

context:
Listener: Mrs. Whinfield, thank you very much for allowing me to visit your wonderful garden. It really helps me a lot to write an article on Dorset gardens for our paper. Now I wonder if I could ask you a few questions.
Speaker: Yes, sure.
Listener: Could you tell me when you became interested in gardening?
Speaker: Well, I was always interested in wild flowers and then in 1980 I read Margery Fish's book Cottage Garden Flowers, which is full of practical advice and personal opinions. But I was reading about plants that I didn't know, so I started to read as much as I could and get different writers' advice. I also used to visit Kew Gardens a lot. That was when we lived in Harrow, West London. I learned a lot from my visit. By the way, Dorset is one of England's three most beautiful towns, the other two being Wiltshire and Somerset. You must know what. I'm often invited to give talks to biology students in college.
Listener: Yes, certainly. That's why I came here. Now what was your first garden like?
Speaker: It was a very tiny piece of land, which came with my house in Harrow, West London.
question: What might happen after what Speaker just said?
a1: after this, the listener may ask the speaker if they faced any challenges in gardening on a small piece of land.
a2: b used the land to grow his garden.

Speaker: Well, I was always interested in wild flowers and then in 1980 I read Margery Fish's book Cottage Garden Flowers, which is full of practical advice and personal opinions. But I was reading about plants that I didn't know, so I started to read as much as I could and get different writers' advice. I also used to visit Kew Gardens a lot. That was when we lived in Harrow, West London. I learned a lot from my visit. By the way, Dorset is one of England's three most beautiful towns, the other two being Wiltshire and Somerset. You must know what. I'm often invited to give talks to biology students in college.
Listener: Yes, certainly. That's why I came here. Now what was your first garden like?
Speaker: It was a very tiny piece of land, which came with my house in Harrow, West London.
question: What might happen after what Speaker just said?
a1: after this, the listener may ask the speaker if they faced any challenges in gardening on a small piece of land.
a2: b used the land to grow his garden.

Speaker: On the...on the ...I'm sorry, I'm too nervous right now. We're on the second floor of Cutler Hall, Room 211.
Listener: I understand, sir. May I have your name and the student's name?
Speaker: Her name is...uh...Anita Rivera. And my name's Lawrence Clark. I'm a professor here at the university.
Listener: Okay, who is there with you?
Speaker: Um, Anita and two other students. They're watching her while I call. Do you think we should drive her to the hospital?
Listener: No, an ambulance is already on its way. It should be there very soon.

Speaker: Okay, well do that. Thank you.
